summary: This is a formal court filing from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, notifying the court of Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide in custody and requesting the dismissal of the criminal case against him via an order of nolle prosequi. The attached order formally disposes of the case due to the defendant's death before final judgment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case who died by suicide while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019, leading to the dismissal of the charges.

persons.name: Richard M. Berman
persons.context: The presiding judge in the case (19 Cr. 490) to whom the letter and proposed order are addressed.

persons.name: Alison Moe
persons.context: One of the prosecutors who signed the letter and the attached nolle prosequi order.

persons.name: Alex Rossmiller
persons.context: One of the prosecutors who signed the letter and the attached nolle prosequi order.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: One of the prosecutors who signed the letter and the attached nolle prosequi order.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted the filing and signed the order.

connections.description: Moe was an Assistant U.S. Attorney prosecuting the case against Epstein.
Rossmiller was an Assistant U.S. Attorney prosecuting the case against Epstein.
Comey was an Assistant U.S. Attorney prosecuting the case against Epstein.
Berman, as U.S. Attorney, was the lead prosecutor overseeing the case against Epstein.
Judge Berman was the presiding judicial officer in the criminal case against Epstein.

events.title: Indictment Returned
events.description: An indictment was returned charging Jeffrey Epstein with one count of conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors and one count of sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by hanging (suicide) while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Autopsy Results Released
events.description: The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City issued a statement identifying the cause of death as hanging and the manner as suicide.

events.title: Filing for Case Dismissal
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office filed a letter and proposed order of nolle prosequi with the court, seeking to dismiss the case due to Epstein's death.

locations: United States Courthouse, 500 Pearl Street, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide (hanging) on August 10, 2019, while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.
The official cause and manner of death were confirmed by the NYC Chief Medical Examiner's Office on August 16, 2019.
Due to Epstein's death before a final judgment, the criminal case against him was subject to abatement, requiring dismissal.
The U.S. Attorney's Office filed a formal request (nolle prosequi) to dismiss the indictment, which charged Epstein with conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors and sex trafficking of minors.
The government stated it had contacted identified victims per the Crime Victims' Rights Act and remained committed to supporting victims.
